section.title: Introduction
section.para: Several &hep; pilot projects had already shown that CPU intensive tasks could easily run on a cloud infrastructure. Members of the group use &opennebula;, &nimbus;, &eucalyptus; and some are evaluating &openstack;. With such a diversity of cloud solutions all under going very active development it is impossible for a group such as &vwg; to only support a single cloud implementation, as we would not be serving the needs to our community.

The &hep; community have long used batch computing models to maximise computing efficiency, this allows jobs to be queued so that each compute node is always occupied. &hep; sites have typically optimised their batch queues so that different user communities can benefit from under utilised resources from other user groups, while retaining a quota of CPU usage proportional to their budget, so called &fss;. It was noted that &hep; users on Clouds typically installed batch queues to maximise their job efficiency but since resources where tied to a single customer it is not possible to use &fss;.

section.title: Scope
section.para: Since &hep; is very conserned with job effciency and has been well served by the batch queue model of computing it was seen that the &vwg; cannot limit thier effort to only working with cloud based solutions and our work scope should be equally applicable to Cloud and ∨ on a batch queue compute node.

One of the side effects of &hep; having pioneared Grid computing, is that the comunity have already learnt about the diversity of sites, and considerable effort has been put into minimising the diffeerances between sites from a customer perspective. The &hep; comunity and sites serving them have come to understand that some areas of site management are not practical to unify. In areas where tools and practices are developing quickly inovation is potentially hindered by enforsing standardisation. This is also true of areas where considerable effort has been invested, and change woudl be detrimental, a good example of this is in site deployment and configuration. The &vwg; decided very early on that we where not going to look into areas that would effect sites local deployment and configuration. The rational was that many sites already had virtulisation stratgies, and sites that did not, should not be prevented from working with newer tools and clound infrastructures.
